content.description: Crack through the steep wall to the left of The Flatiron. Crack starts out steep with good finger locks and abundant gear placements. Avoid stepping off to ledge on the right as it defeats the purpose of surmounting the lower moves.  Bottom portion of the route ends at a large jug.  From the jug place large cams and get ready to pull hard 5.10 laybacking and/or offwith.  Finish is tricky and strenuous but not as difficult.  The whole route barely makes 35 ft., I think, and it is strangely stout.
content.protection: Medium Wires, Mid to Large size Cams, Tricams.

content.description:
The Bodysnatcher is a finger crack leading to an OW crack is a box, capped by a roof. Climb up cracks and exit around the roof to the left.  

  The Bodysnatcher Direct: 5.10c, Climb the beginning of Bodysnatcher to the roof and pull straight over the roof.
content.protection: Standard Rack and a big piece or two.
content.location: 25 feet west (left) of The Monster & The Little Flatiron

content.description: Up the short wall, just left of the "Body Snatcher," then up the crack and flake.
content.location: Just left of the "Body Snatcher".  Belay from the trail or from the ledge above the trail.

content.description:
Start in the trail, where it passes between the wall and a tree.  Your belayer will have to keep an eye out for hikers (there is room to step off to the side). 

  Use juggy holds to get up on the bench.  Work up the thin seam until you can move right to the corner, and finish up to the top.
content.protection: Small nuts and small cams are key, at the crux.
content.location: Left of "The Thing" is a smooth, slightly overhanging wall.  Around the corner to the left are some thin cracks in the face.

content.description: The Monster is a short wall containing a dozen climbs of varying difficulty.  The Monster could even be considered a fine area for some highball bouldering problems.
